serStmt.serInfo: The Canadian Tobacco Use Monitoring Survey was conducted for Health Canada to provide data on tobacco use and related issues. The primary objective of the survey is to track changes in smoking status, especially for population most at risk, such as the 15-24 years olds. The survey will allow Health Canada to estimate smoking prevalence for age groups 15-24 and 25+ by province and by gender on a semi-annual basis.

serStmt.serInfo: The Canadian Tobacco Use Monitoring Survey was conducted for Health Canada to provide data on tobacco use and related issues. The primary objective of the survey is to track changes in smoking status, especially for population most at risk, such as the 15-24 years olds. The survey will allow Health Canada to estimate smoking prevalence for age groups 15-24 and 25+ by province and by gender on a semi-annual basis.

verStmt.notes:
All sas/spss programs, and documentation files have been replaced due to errors in labels. Data file NOT replaced. Dec 17, 2002 cp.

NOTES: Some variables are suppressed. Please check codebooks for details.

NOTE TO: Users of the Canadian Tobacco Use Monitoring Survey (Cycle 2 2001 and Cycle 1 2002) March 21, 2003

Because of anomalies found in the data, Statistics Canada will be issuing a new version of the Canadian Tobacco Use Monitoring Survey (Cycle 2 2001 and Cycle 1 2002) data files.

There were some coding errors in questions Q088_A to Q088_O and some minor flow errors that affect the number of 'valid skips' and 'not stated' (in particular Q111). Any estimates being produced from these questions will need to be recalculated with the new dataset. There will also be a change in the record layout when the file is reissued.

Any questions regarding the use of the files can be directed to Karen oberts, Chief, Health and Volunteerism Section, Special Surveys Division by telephone at (613) 951-3726 or by email at robekar@statcan.ca.

Summary derived from Users Guide.
Updated 2002/12 cp

stdyInfo.abstract:
Statistics Canada has conducted smoking surveys on an ad hoc basis on behalf of Health Canada since the 1960s. These surveys have been done as supplements to the Canadian Labour Force Survey and as Random Digit Dialling telephone surveys.

In February 1994, a change in legislation was passed which allowed a reduction in cigarette taxes. Since there was no survey data from immediately before this legislative change took place, it was difficult for Health Canada or other interested analysts to measure exactly the impact of the change. As Health Canada wants to be able to monitor the consequences of legislative changes and anti-smoking policies on smoking behaviour, the Canadian Tobacco Use Monitoring Survey was designed to provide Health Canada and its partners/stakeholders with continual and reliable data on tobacco use and related issues.

Since 1999, two CTUMS files have been released every year: a file with data collected from February to June and a file with the July to December data. Additionally, there is also a yearly summary.

The survey is presented in three cycles: Cycle 1 - taken Feb-June 2001; Cycle 2 - taken July-Dec 2001; and Cycle Annual - combining both time periods. Each cycle contains two files; household data, and person data.

The primary objective of the survey is to provide a continuous supply of smoking prevalence data against which changes in prevalence can be monitored. This objective differs from that of the National Population Health Survey which collects smoking data from a longitudinal sample to measure which individuals are changing their smoking behaviour, the possible factors which contribute to change, and the possible risk factors related to starting smoking and smoking duration. Because the NPHS collects data every two years and releases the data about a year after completing the collection cycle, it does not meet Health Canada’s need for continuous coverage in time, rapid delivery of data, or sufficient detail of the most at-risk populations, namely 15-24 year olds.

The Tobacco Use Monitoring Survey allows Health Canada to look at smoking prevalence by province-sex-age group, for age groups 15-19, 20- 24, 25-34, 35-44 and 45+ on a semi-annual and annual basis. Data will continue to be collected on an on-going basis depending on availability of funds.

sumDscr.universe: Included: Population of Canada aged 15 years and over
Excluded: Residents of Yukon and Northwest Territories, Nunavut, institutionalized persons and residents without phones.

useStmt.restrctn: The data is restricted to use by current students, faculty and staff of Ontario Council of University Libraries (OCUL) Member Libraries for academic research and teaching only.
useStmt.citReq: The publishing of analysis and results from research using any of the data products is permitted in research communications such as scholarly papers, journals and the like. The authors of these communications are required to cite Statistics Canada as the source of the data, and to indicate that the results or views expressed are those of the author/authorized user and are not those of Statistics Canada. Permission to include extracts of these data in textbooks must be obtained from the Licencing Section of Statistics Canada's Marketing Division.

var.name: CH010
var.labl: Does anyone in your household smoke cigarettes, cigars or pipes?

var.name: H020
var.labl: No. of people that smoke INSIDE the hhld

qstn.qstnLit: Including both family members and regular visitors, how many people smoke INSIDE your home every day or almost every day?
qstn.ivuInstr: PROBE: Please include cigarette, cigar and pipe smoking.

var.name: H025
var.labl: No. of cigs. smoked INSIDE your home in a day?

qstn.qstnLit: On a typical day, how many cigarettes are smoked INSIDE your home?
qstn.ivuInstr: DO NOT READ LIST.

var.universe: Households where at least one person smokes inside the home
var.notes: Help: 20 cigarettes is about 1 pack. 40 cigarettes is about 2 packs. 60 cigarettes is about 3 packs.

var.name: H026
var.labl: Is smoking cigs. allowed in your home

qstn.qstnLit: Is smoking cigarettes allowed inside your home?

var.universe: Household with no regular smokers inside the home or where no cigarettes are smoked inside home.

var.name: H027
var.labl: Is smoking cigs. restricted in your home in any way?

qstn.qstnLit: Is smoking cigarettes restricted in any way inside your home?

var.universe: Household where no smoker inside home but smoking is allowed or where cigarettes are smoked inside home.

qstn.ivuInstr: Mark all that apply

qstn.ivuInstr: Mark all that apply

qstn.ivuInstr: Mark all that apply

var.labl: How is smoking cigarettes restricted inside your home?... Other (specify)

qstn.ivuInstr: Mark all that apply

var.name: H028_F

var.name: Q097A
var.labl: Asked age when buying cigarettes in store

qstn.qstnLit: In the past 12 months, have you been asked your age when buying cigarettes in a store for yourself or for someone else?

var.name: Q099A
var.labl: What strength of cigarettes do you smoke?

qstn.qstnLit: What strength of cigarettes do you usually smoke?
qstn.ivuInstr: Read the list

var.name: Q099D
var.labl: Believe strength of cigarettes smoked reduces risks without quitting

qstn.preQTxt: Now, I’m going to ask you about reasons some people might give for smoking light/mild cigarettes. For each one, please tell me whether it is one of your reasons for smoking light/mild cigarettes.
qstn.qstnLit: Do you smoke <prefill Q99A> cigarettes because you believe they reduce the risks of smoking without having to actually give up smoking?

var.universe: Current daily or occasional smokers not smoking regular cigarettes

var.name: Q099E
var.labl: Believe strength of cigarettes smoked reduces amount of tar you inhale

qstn.preQTxt: Now, I’m going to ask you about reasons some people might give for smoking light/mild cigarettes. For each one, please tell me whether it is one of your reasons for smoking light/mild cigarettes.
qstn.qstnLit: Do you smoke <prefill Q99A> cigarettes because you believe they reduce the amount of tar you inhale, compared to regular cigarettes?

var.universe: Current daily or occasional smokers not smoking regular cigarettes

var.name: Q099F
var.labl: Believe strength of cigarettes smoked reduces the risk to your health

qstn.preQTxt: Now, I’m going to ask you about reasons some people might give for smoking light/mild cigarettes. For each one, please tell me whether it is one of your reasons for smoking light/mild cigarettes.
qstn.qstnLit: Do you smoke <prefill Q99A> cigarettes because you believe they reduce the risk to your health compared to regular cigarettes?

var.universe: Current daily or occasional smokers not smoking regular cigarettes

var.labl: What would it take for you to quit smoking - change of lifestyle

qstn.qstnLit: What would it take for you to quit smoking ... change of lifestyle (different job, less stress)?

var.name: DVSST1
var.labl: D.V. for type 1 smoking status
var.notes: SOSIC (Survey of Smoking in Canada) definition

var.name: DVSST2
var.labl: D.V. for type 2 smoking status

var.name: DVSS1
var.labl: D.V. for type 1 smoking status

catgry.labl: Never smoked or less than 100 in life

var.name: DVSS2
var.labl: D.V. for type 2 smoking status

catgry.labl: Former daily but not last 30 days

var.name: DVCIGWK
var.labl: D.V. for no. of cigs smoke/wk

var.name: DVAVCIG7
var.labl: D.V. avg. no. of cigs smoked/day
var.notes: Averaged over 7 days. Occasional smokers who haven't smoked in the past 30 days have been excluded, unlike SOSIC (Survey of Smoking in Canada).

var.name: DVNDSMK
var.labl: D.V. no. of days smoked in last 7 days

var.name: DVAVCIGD
var.labl: D.V. avg. smoked on the days they smoked

var.name: STOPSMK
var.labl: D.V. no. of mths no smoke since survey

var.name: DVYRSSMK
var.labl: D.V. no. of yrs the respondent smoked
var.notes: Derived from respondent's age and Q065

var.name: DVEVRREF
var.labl: D.V. anyone in store refuse to sell cigs

var.name: DVSMKPTN
var.labl: D.V. for current smokers smoking pattern
var.notes: SOSIC only included smokers that smoked in the past 7 days instead of 30 days.

var.name: DVEDUC
var.labl: D.V. highest level of education obtained
var.notes: SOSIC (Survey of Smoking in Canada) definition) If Q170 = 01,02,03,04 then DVEDUC = 1; If Q170 = 05,06,08,10 then DVEDUC = 2; If Q170 = 07 then DVEDUC = 3; If Q170 = 09 then DVEDUC = 4

var.name: DVINCAD
var.labl: D.V. Income adequacy
var.notes: More categories than SOSIC (Survey of Smoking in Canada) definition

var.name: HHTYPE
var.labl: D.V. Type of hhld based on age

var.name: T_AGE
var.labl: D.V. Age of respondent
var.notes: On public use file, ages greater than 85 were recoded to 85.

var.name: P_AGEGRP
var.labl: D.V. Age of respondent - in ranges

var.name: WGT6MO
var.labl: Six month weight
